abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Outcome
            is unsatisfactory, sustainability is unlikely, institutional
            development impact is negligible, and the performances of
            both the Bank and the Borrower are unsatisfactory. Lessons
            learned centered on the subproject selection process
            (inadequate preparation, lobbying by local governments and
            pressures on consultants to manipulate analysis). In future
            programmatic projects, particular attention has to be given
            to avoid "scaling up" the original project design
            when government capacity and commitment are weak. Second,
            the Bank team was originally supposed to supervise the
            supervisors. This was an ineffective strategy because of the
            weak staffing of Provincial Project Management Units and
            poorly performing consultants, largely hired locally. In
            future projects, project management staffing at different
            levels should be screened and approved by the Bank.
            Similarly, the consulting firms shortlisted for bidding
            should be screened more closely regarding their competence
            and previous performance record. Other lessons for the Bank
            regarded more systematic follow-up, the need for early Bank
            management involvement and prompt action on suspected
            corruption, timely use of Bank remedies, the importance of
            paying attention to cultural factors. Particular lessons for
            the Government related to the need for using suitable
            intermediaries, defining clearly the responsibilities
            (including fiscal)of the central, provincial and local
            governments, defining the government's responsibility
            for supervision, the need to improve the incentive system,
            giving priority to the training program, the need for close
            monitoring and supervision, following a systematic process
            of consultant screening and evaluation, lack of attention to
            bank-recommended tools such as the preparation and regular
            updating of the Revenue Improvement Action Plan (RIAP) and
            the use of the Performance-Oriented Maintenance Management
            Systems (POMMS), and the lack of attention to operation and
            maintenance. Shared lessons comprised strengthening
            financial management oversight, consultant selection and
            professional management, strengthening the  procurement
            system, and technical audits and completion certification. A
            major lesson is that it is necessary to make communities
            aware of the project scope and objectives through an active
            socialization process based on meetings, workshops and focus
            group discussions using local facilitators when needed. An
            important part of the socialization process should be to let
            people know where to go if they are not satisfied with the
            project's outcome. Thus the project preparation period
            should include the project socialization process as well.
            This requires more active focus on the public information
            function by making, if necessary, translations of relevant
            Bank documents for local use.
